The wording of the question is very interesting in itself! 
First point is what body does the question suggest would be setting a date for a referendum? The body that would set a date would be the Scottish Parliament. But according to the current legal settlement the Scottish Parliament could only do that with the agreement of the UK Government. So if the Scottish Government set a date for a referendum on Scotland's status without the agreement of the UK Government it would be acting illegally.   The SNP has the largest number of seats in the Scottish Parliament (62) but does not have a majority (of the 129 seats). Only the SNP is in favour of changing Scotland's status within the UK. No election to the Scottish Parliament is due to be held until May 2021. So in order to have a majority the Scottish Parliament would need to be dissolved and new elections would need to be held, and the SNP would need to gain a majority of seats. This seems very unlikely to happen in the next year (say a 5% chance). If somehow the SNP have a majority they would either need to get the UK Government to agree to a referendum or act illegally to decide to hold one and set a date. The SNP has (so far) been clear that it sees the chaos that has been caused by Catalonia holding an illegal referendum on independence from Spain (politicians being fined and/or sent to jail) that it does not want to go down that route. An illegal referendum would also risk upsetting the EU when if Scotland became independent from the UK one of its objectives would be to re-join the EU. For fairly obvious reasons the EU does not want the practice of holding illegal independence referendums spreading to would be break away regions to other EU countries. So I think we can totally discount Scotland setting a date for an illegal referendum. Its also likely that strategically the SNP would do better to see the effects of Brexit over the next couple of years. It would be logical to see businesses contract when the UK fully leaves the EU Single Market and Customs Union, before they can expand to take advantage of the opportunities of not being constrained by being in the EU. In short the UK and Scottish economy will take any Brexit hit before it gets any benefit. So the best time for an independence referendum would be at the bottom of this economic dip.  I assume that the UK Government is aware that its likely to get worse before it gets better and if it offered Scotland another referendum having it after the dip would be better. The UK PM has already ruled out another Scottish referendum in the foreseeable future. I see no likelihood that he changes his mind in the next few months. As the majority of Scottish voters do not want to leave the EU trying to get an independence referendum out of the way before a Brexit slump hits would be a big risk for the UK Government as Scottish voters might see voting for independence as a last chance to avoid Sexit (Scottish exit of the EU).
